text: reports are still coming in but
government officials they say that
gunmen have killed at least eight people
mostly tourists at a museum next to the
Parliament building in the capital Tunis
officials say that the gunmen are
holding other tourists hostage in the
Bardo Museum let's get more on this our
world affairs correspondent Paul Adams
joins us here in the studio Paul what
more do we know it's still a very very
unclear situation you know it does seem
to be still going on it's pretty clear I
think that this is not as some people
were assuming at the beginning an attack
on the nearby Parliament which did go
straight into lockdown it does seem to
be a very deliberate targeted attack
against one of two nurses main tourist
attractions the Bardo Museum full of
very significant artifacts there are
pictures being tweeted out from inside
the museum which appear to show tourists
some local some foreigners on the ground
there's even one curious photo which
shows the back of someone who looks to
all intents and purposes like a member
of the military and there were some
suggestions that these armed people got
into the museum dressed in military
uniform so we're not quite sure what the
what the what the appearance of these
attackers is or indeed how many there
are
two or three some suggestion that one
had already fled possibly taking some
tourists with him but I think it does
seem to be a situation in which we have
hostages being held inside the museum as
you say in the last that half an hour or
so a spokesman for the interior ministry
said that there were eight dead one
Tunisian and one has to assume seven
tourists and lots of nationalities being
talked about or either as talking about
that those who are dead or probably
those who are still inside as hostages
French Spanish British Italian and
Tunisian as you say lots of different
nationalities there just briefly a Paul
you know since Bin Ali was a stood in
the situation in the country has
remained
unstable I mean is there a growing
presence of Islamic states there yes
that is very much the fear and it is
worth remembering that the largest
single number of foreign jihadi fighters
participating in Islamic state in Iraq
and Syria come from Tunisia and there
are increasing fears of violence
spilling over the border from
neighboring Libya with some suggestion
that a cell was wrapped up even today
before news of this attack with links to
militants from Libya so I think given
the the the slightly unstable political
situation better than most post Arab
Spring countries it has to be said but
still difficult and this this
participation of so many young Tunisians
in Islamic state an attack like this in
Tunisia itself was probably only a
matter of time yes you're looking at
some pictures from a Tunisian TV we're
getting reports that schools of injured
have now been rushed to various
hospitals in Tunis and the Interior
Ministry has said the majority of the
foreign hostages have been evacuated
we're also hearing reports that
government forces security forces have
entered that Museum in the country's
capital where it's believed that
militants are holding some of the
hostages
